metadata.case_name: K. S. Srinivasan v. Union of India

facts.text: On May 1, 1946, Shri K. S. Srinivasan appointed as Liaison Officer, All India Radio, on pay of Rs. 350 per month in scale Rs. 350-20-450-25/2-550, on recommendation of Federal Public Service Commission. Posts permanent and pensionable but filled temporarily on probation for six months.
Designation Liaison Officer changed to Public Relations Officer. Posts of Public Relations Officers upgraded to Rs. 450-25-500-30-800 with effect from January 1, 1947.

On May 23, 1952, Director General, All India Radio, appointed appellant to Public Relations Officer grade in quasi-permanent capacity w.e.f. May 1, 1949, after continuous service over three years and concurrence of Union Public Service Commission.
On September 3, 1952, appellant received order that services not required after October 6, 1952.
Appellant made representation on September 8, 1952, claiming right to alternative post in same grade as quasi-permanent officer.
On September 13, 1952, appellant appointed to officiate as Assistant Station Director, Madras, in purely temporary capacity until further orders.
In August 1952, all posts of Public Relations Officers except one in External Services Division held in abeyance.
Appellant appeared before Union Public Service Commission on March 26, 1953, for Assistant Station Director posts; not selected on April 18, 1953.
On July 3, 1953, memorandum stated posts of Public Relations Officers form separate cadre from Assistant Station Directors; appellant cannot claim protection.

Order dated December 14, 1953: Appellant carries quasi-permanent status of former Public Relations Officer post while holding Assistant Station Director post, as posts in same grade per Ministry of Home Affairs O.M. No. 54/136/51-NGS dated April 24, 1952.
On August 31, 1955, informed Union Public Service Commission objected to appointment as contrary to regulations; asked to relinquish post or accept lower temporary Assistant Information Officer post.
Order dated September 7, 1955: Appellant required to relinquish Assistant Station Director post; offered temporary Assistant Information Officer post (lower scale Rs. 350-25-500-EB-30-620).
On October 11, 1955, transferred to Press Information Bureau as officiating Assistant Information Officer.
Appellant filed Writ Petition No. 209-D of 1955 in Punjab High Court on November 25, 1955; summarily dismissed same day.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on April 23, 1956.
Petition under Art. 32 filed on April 22, 1956, challenging orders under Arts. 14 and 16.

legal_issues.text: Whether the impugned orders violate Art. 311(2) of the Constitution, as appellant had right to post of Assistant Station Director due to quasi-permanent status carried from Public Relations Officer post under Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949.
Whether posts of Public Relations Officer and Assistant Station Director are in same grade or cadre for purpose of proviso to Rule 6(1)(ii) of Temporary Service Rules.
Whether order dated December 14, 1953 constitutes independent declaration of quasi-permanent status in Assistant Station Director post under Rules 3 and 4.
Whether impugned orders violate Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant held quasi-permanent status in Public Relations Officer grade under Temporary Service Rules, 1949, and carried it to Assistant Station Director post as same grade; entitled to retention in service in same grade post.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949, rr. 3,4,6(1)(ii) proviso; Art. 311

petitioner_arguments.text: Posts of Public Relations Officer and Assistant Station Director in same grade (same pay scale, Class II, Programme side); reduction did not occur as posts held in abeyance, not reduced.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Fundamental Rule 9(4), Art. 29 Civil Service Regulations

petitioner_arguments.text: Order dated December 14, 1953 admits same grade and carries status; Union Public Service Commission opinion not binding.

respondent_arguments.text: Impugned orders in consonance with Temporary Service Rules; quasi-permanent service in Public Relations Officer post liable to termination under r.6(1)(ii) due to reduction; Assistant Station Director post not same grade/cadre.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949, r.6(1)(ii)

respondent_arguments.text: Order dated December 14, 1953 issued under misapprehension; not independent declaration; no consultation with UPSC as required by r.4(b).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Temporary Service Rules r.4(b); Union Public Service Commission (Consultation) Regulations

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant appointed temporarily to Assistant Station Director; rejected by UPSC in open selection.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 311(2) applies only if servant has right to post; termination otherwise not punishment. Appellant had no right to Assistant Station Director post as temporary appointee without quasi-permanent status ripening there.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Termination of service deprives right only if servant had right to post under contract or rules.

court_reasoning.text: Public Relations Officer posts form separate cadre/grade from Assistant Station Directors per 1944 reorganisation, 1950 cadre declaration, A.I.R. Manual; same pay scale insufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cadre means strength of service as separate unit; Public Relations Officers not included in Assistant Station Directors cadre.

court_reasoning.text: December 14, 1953 order not independent declaration under rr.3,4; merely carries status from former post on mistaken view of same grade, per Home Ministry O.M.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order recites carrying status from former post; no new specification of post/date as required by r.4(a).

court_reasoning.text: Reduction occurred by holding posts in abeyance (no intention to revive); certified via memoranda.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reduction in cl.(ii) includes holding in abeyance; not limited to abolition.

court_reasoning.text: No violation of Arts.14,16; non-selection by UPSC unfortunate but no discrimination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Others appointed via selection; no breach of fundamental rights.

court_reasoning.text: Bose J. dissent: December 14, 1953 order unequivocally confers quasi-permanent status in new post; r.4(b) directory, not mandatory; equity demands protection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Public orders construed objectively; Government intended to confer status; mistake unilateral.

holdings.text: Impugned orders do not violate Art. 311(2); no right to Assistant Station Director post; quasi-permanent status not carried as different grade/cadre; appeal and petition dismissed.
Posts of Public Relations Officer and Assistant Station Director not same grade/cadre.

precedents_cited.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of Art. 311; termination is punishment only if deprives right to post.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava
Commissioner of Police, Bombay v. Gordhandas Bhanji
precedents_cited.relevance: Public orders construed objectively by language, not subsequent explanations. (Cited in dissent)
Similar provision in s.256 Govt. of India Act directory. (In dissent)

precedents_cited.case_name: Montreal Street Railway Company v. Normandin
precedents_cited.relevance: Statutory formalities directory if mandatory causes inconvenience/injustice. (In dissent)

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Protection against termination without opportunity if punishment; equality; no discrimination in service.

statutes_cited.name: Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Quasi-permanent status, termination on reduction, carrying status within same grade/cadre.

statutes_cited.name: Union Public Service Commission (Consultation) Regulations
statutes_cited.relevance: No consultation needed for certain internal appointments.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave and Art.32 petition dismissed; no violation of Art.311(2),14,16; appellant had no right to Assistant Station Director post; invited sympathetic consideration for relief.

key_quotes.text: "If the servant has no right to the post... the termination of his employment does not deprive him of any right and cannot, therefore, by itself, be a punishment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for Art.311 applicability from Parshotam Lal Dhingra.

key_quotes.text: "Public orders, publicly made... must be construed objectively with reference to the language used in the order itself."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Objective construction of orders (dissent, but cited majority precedent).

key_quotes.text: "This is a hard case... we invite the attention of the authorities concerned... and hope that they will consider the appellant's case sympathetically."
key_quotes.speaker: court
